Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Collaborative Research: Leading Edge Vortex Evolution on Compliant Biologically-Inspired Wings

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1511507(Willis) and 1510962(Jones)

This is a collaborative proposal that will utilize experiments and computations to investigate the flow field generated around a flexible wing. While a lot of research has been done to understand how lift forces are generated around solid wings, it is important to also understand why and how soft, flexible wings are used to generate lift. Fundamental knowledge generated through this work can impact both biological sciences as well as the autonomous drone industries (commercial and military).

A lot of prior research work has been done on rigid wings, showing that wing kinematics can alter the strength and position of the shear layer that feeds the so-called leading edge vortices (LEVs) that are responsible for the bulk of the lift forces. The vortex dynamics have been shown to result in fluid dynamic forces. More recently, LEVs have been observed on moderate Reynolds number, and in morphing and compliant wings during low speed flight and maneuvering of insects. The proposed project will advance this area of research by investigating wing compliance effects, by examining the vortices generated at the leading edge at moderate Reynolds numbers (where the LEV is a significant but not necessarily dominant source of lift) and by quantifying importance of wing compliance and vortex dynamics to lift force production. Furthermore, educational activities are proposed via integration of research results into university courses as well as the development of several instructional materials for local K-12 schools in both Massachusetts and Maryland.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The aggressive wing motions common in natural flight often result in separated flow and the formation of a leading-edge vortex (LEV). The LEV forms from the separated shear layer that emanates from the leading edge of the wing. This shear layer continues to feed the vortex, increasing its circulation until it eventually breaks off of the wing and is convected downstream. Water tank experiments on a surging flat plate wing at a high angle of attack were performed at varying Reynolds number, acceleration, angle of attack, and aspect ratio to measure lift and drag, LEV location, LEV circulation, and leading-edge circulation production. These data were then used to explore how the LEV and the circulation production react to changes in wing motion; a new relationship between the wake behind the wing and the leading-edge circulation production was proposed. Additionally, state-of-the-art potential flow modeling techniques were implemented and evaluated with respect to the experimental data to assess the suitability of applying the Kutta condition at the leading edge. The Kutta condition was found to be a reasonable leading-edge boundary condition, and was capable of predicting the LEV circulation observed in experiments. Representing the shed wake with multiple vortices was found to be necessary to capture the dynamics of vortex roll up and shedding, which is critical because it is directly related to unsteady aerodynamic forcing. Simpler flow models struggle to account for these events, though they may offer a better route to an intuitive understanding of the fluid dynamic origin of the forces. The experimental data collected here, coupled with the novel analysis of the modeling techniques in the light of the leading-edge circulation measurements, constitutes a significant step forward in the understanding and modeling of separated flows and unsteady aerodynamic forcing.

 


Last Modified: 10/31/2018
Modified by: Anya Jones

These data were then used to explore how the LEV and the circulation production react to changes in wing motion; a new relationship between the wake behind the wing and the leading-edge circulation production was proposed. Additionally, state-of-the-art potential flow modeling techniques were implemented and evaluated with respect to the experimental data to assess the suitability of applying the Kutta condition at the leading edge. The Kutta condition was found to be a reasonable leading-edge boundary condition, and was capable of predicting the LEV circulation observed in experiments. Representing the shed wake with multiple vortices was found to be necessary to capture the dynamics of vortex roll up and shedding, which is critical because it is directly related to unsteady aerodynamic forcing. Simpler flow models struggle to account for these events, though they may offer a better route to an intuitive understanding of the fluid dynamic origin of the forces.
